Primary Offense: Medicare Parts C and D Enforcement Action
Description: improper contract administration

The Justice Department announced that Evercare Hospice and Palliative Care would pay $18 million to resolve False Claims Act allegations that it claimed Medicare reimbursement for hospice care for patients who were not eligible for such care because they were not terminally ill.  Evercare, now known as Optum Palliative and Hospice Care, is a Minnesota-based provider of hospice care in Arizona, Colorado and other states across the United States.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Private Litigation Case Title: Robert Cohen v. United HealthCare Services, Inc.
Zilhaver v. UnitedHealth Group, Inc. et al

Description: HealthMarkets, Inc., and its subsidiaries, the MEGA Life and Health Insurance and Mid-West National Life Insurance, agreed to pay $13.35 million in consumer relief, $3 million in civil penalties, and $750,000 costs, in settlement of allegations they engaged in unfair and deceptive practices in marketing and administration of health plans sold to small businesses and individuals in Massachusetts.

Company: MEGA Life and Health Insurance Company
Description: The Maine Bureau of Insurance and the Maine Attorney General resolved concerns about what they called MEGA Life and Health Insurance Company's flawed method of determining premiums for individual health insurance policies, including payment of a $1 million fine against the company. MEGA Life was also required to refund $4.6 million in overpaid premiums, plus interest, to consumers.

The New York Attorney announced agreements with six health maintenance organizations that would empower consumers to challenge denials of coverage. The HMOs also agreed to pay a total of $1 million to the state AG's office to cover the cost of the investigation. The announcement did not specify how that cost would be divided among the six plans. Here we assume it was split equally.

Company: Oxford Health Plans of New York

Description: dispute over unpaid claims
Info Source: Pacificare Works to End Pending Litigation with Texas, Bestwire, March 24, 2003 (via Nexis).

Description: To resolve a case involving allegations of unfair health insurance reimbursement rates, UnitedHealth agreed to pay $50 million to a qualified nonprofit organization that would establish a new, independent database to help determine fair out-of-network reimbursement rates for consumers throughout the United States.
UnitedHealth agreed to make $15 million in charitable contributions and pay $875,000 to the state to resolve litigation concerning its acquisition of Sierra Health Services Inc.

Aetna, CareFirst BlueChoice, and UnitedHealthcare each agreed to pay $50,000 in settlement of allegations they provided flawed health directories that made it difficult for consumers to access mental health services.

Agency: New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance
Info Source: TWO NEW JERSEY FINES TOTAL MORE THAN $400,000 FOR HMOS, Bestwire, April 6, 2000 (via Nexis).

Description: New Jersey has fined two health maintenance organizations a total of more than $400,000 for violations that include failure to pay claims on time and failing to remove from a network a doctor with a suspended license.
Agency: New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance
Info Source: TWO NEW JERSEY FINES TOTAL MORE THAN $400,000 FOR HMOS, Bestwire, April 6, 2000 (via Nexis).

Company: Health Net of New Jersey, Inc.
Description: Health Net was fined $60,000 and ordered to pay restitution of $814,000 for failing to provide mandated infertility benefits and using an outdated fee schedule to reimburse providers and consumers.
Agency: New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance
New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance
New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance

Company: Health Net of New Jersey, Inc.
Description: Consolidated Consent Order #E06-44, March 3, 2006; HMO's predecessor, Physician's Health Services of New Jersey, Inc., engaged in improper business practices set forth in a market conduct examination report adopted on January 2, 2003; and Health Net improperly refused to cover certain out-of-network surgical center charges and issued inaccurate, deceptive and misleading letters to certain SEH members that created the false impression that the services were not covered benefits.  Sanctions:  Fine - $325,000; Restitution:  Approximately $100,000 - to be determined by audit.
Agency: New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance
New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance

Company: Health Net of New Jersey, Inc.
Description: Health Net misrepresented to the Department that it wished to implement a proposed repricing methodology which, in fact, had already been put to use; Health Net's use of the repricing methodology violated small group regulations and was not in accordance with the provision of its large group contracts approved prior to April 2005; Health Net violated the terms of its small group contracts by failing to cover a 96-hour supply of certain prescription drugs; Health Net's protocols from May 2005 to September 2006 failed to provide coverage for one or more therapies appropriate to treat children with autism/pervasive developmental disorder, and in instances Health Net denied coverage, in violation of the biologically-based mental illness mandate; Health Net tiered reimbursement for certain out-of-network mental health benefits based on the professional designation of the provider which violated small group rules and which was not in accordance with its large group contracts approved prior to April 2005; and Health Net failed to timely file with the Department the administrative services agreement between it and Health Net of the Northeast, Inc. (its parent) covering administrative, consulting and other support services.  Remediation is being made to adversely affected members or medical providers.
Agency: New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance
New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance
New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance
New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance

Company: Health Net of New Jersey, Inc.
Description: Health Net systemically under-reimbursed certain types of claims, affecting approximately 88,000 members; failed to initially disclose to the Department the true extent of under-reimbursements; failed to initially properly remediate under-reimbursements; and improperly denied certain claims for lack of pre-authorization, Sanctions: Restitution - $26 million; Fine - $13 million; Costs - $2 million.
Agency: New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance
New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance

Company: Oxford Health Plans (NJ), Inc. and United Healthcare of New Jersey, Inc.
Description: Market conduct examinations reveal instances of noncompliance with applicable statutes and regulations.
Agency: New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance

Description: Respondent untimely processed certain prior authorization requests and inappropriately denied certain claims as untimely.
Agency: New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance
New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance

Company: Oxford Health Insurance, Inc. and UnitedHealthcare Insurance Company
Description: The Department found that respondents implemented prior authorization/medical necessity programs for certain prescription drugs that resulted in the denial of medically necessary services, improperly denied inpatient treatment for persons suffering from multiple serious mental illnesses, improperly issued and offered to issue small employer plans with retiree coverage, and improperly delayed in complying with a decision of the Independent Health Care Appeals Program.
Agency: New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance

Description: Members were subject to collection activities for services for which their responsibility was limited to network cost sharing and Respondents issued Summary of Benefit and Coverage forms with inaccurate cost sharing information.
Agency: New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance

Description: UnitedHealthcare and two of its subsidiaries were fined $2.5 million for using an entity for the provision of hemophilia supplies and services that lacked the required state designation and improperly required member consent for provider payment appeals.  Americhoice of New Jersey, Inc. failed to promptly comply with decisions of the Independent Health Care Appeals Program that reversed its denials of authorization and claims.   Oxford Health Insurance, Inc. failed to provide utilization management appeal rights to persons covered by individual health benefits plans who sought an override of a prescription drug quantity limit and provided incorrect information to callers and on its website about the individual health benefits plans it offered in New Jersey.
Agency: New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance

Description: Oxford Health Insurance Inc., a unit of UnitedHealth Group, agreed to refund $50 million to about 37,000 small businesses in New York for overcharging on health insurance policies in 2006.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: Fine levied for failing to make its decision regarding an appeal within thirty days of the date the appeal is received, and by failing to respond as expeditiously as possible to an expedited review request. RCW 48.43.530(5)(c); WAC 284-43-3170(4).
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: $50,000 fine levied for improperly denying women's health services to 276 Washington consumers, for failing to process an oral complaint from a Washington consumer regarding the denial of benefits, and for failing to respond to a Washington consumer's two (2) appeals of an adverse benefit determinat...
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: $30,000 fine levied for failing to maintain a log of grievances that tracks complaints, describes the nature of the complaints and the Company's responses thereto, failing to provide a full and complete appeals log, failing to afford medical providers five (5) calendar days to submit information the...
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: $5,000 fine levied for failing to use its legal name in 297 correspondences to insureds and providers. RCW 48.05.190(1); RCW 48.30.010(1); WAC 284-30-670.
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: Golden Rule agreed to pay forfeitures of $275,000 and $385,000 in penalties for lack of cooperation to a group of states to resolve alleged violations in its advertising practices.

HealthMarkets agreed to pay $20 million to a group of state following a three-year investigation which found multiple problems involving consumer disclosure, oversight and training of agents, claims handling and complaint-handling practices.
Info Source: $20 MILLION FINE LEVIED AGAINST INSURER TO SETTLE MISCONDUCT PROBE, US States News, July 24, 2008 (via Nexis).

Company: MEGA Life and Health Insurance Company et al.
Description: MEGA Life and affiliated companies agreed to pay $20 million to a group of state insurance regulators to resolve issues relating to disclosure, claims handling and other matters.

United HealthCare agreed to pay up to $20 million to a group of states following an investigation that found many errors in claim processing, such as not applying correct fee schedules and not applying deductibles correctly. Also, the company frequently violated prompt payment rules. And because of poor controls and oversight, the company was generally unable to correct problems when they were brought to its attention by state regulators.
Info Source: COMMISSIONER VOSS LEADER IN HISTORIC $20 MILLION SETTLEMENT, US States News, September 6, 2007 (via Nexis).

Description: United Behavioral Health and UnitedHealthcare Insurance Co. agreed to pay $13.6 million to affected participants and beneficiaries; pay $2,084,249 in penalties; and take other corrective actions following investigations and litigation by the U.S. Department of Labor and the New York State Attorney General. An investigation by the department' Employee Benefits Security Administration found that going back to at least 2013 United reduced reimbursement rates for out-of-network mental health services, thereby overcharging participants for those services, and flagged participants undergoing mental health treatments for a utilization review, resulting in many denials of payment for those services. The settlement was also announced by the New York AG (see separate entry).

Company: United Healthcare of Louisiana, Inc. and OptumRx, Inc.
Description: UHC-LA and OptumRx agreed to jointly pay $25,000 in settlement of alleged violations of health insurance regulations.

UnitedHealthcare agreed to pay a $1.3 million penalty to New York as part of a larger settlement with the U.S. Department of Labor and the state to resolve allegations it unlawfully denied health care coverage for mental health and substance use disorder treatment. The larger settlement was also announced by DOL (see separate entry).

Company: UHC of California dba UnitedHealthcare of California
Agency: California Department of Managed Health Care

Description: UnitedHealthcare Insurance Company, UnitedHealthcare of Texas, Inc., National Pacific Dental, Inc., and Golden Rule Insurance Company agreed to pay a total of $2.6 million in settlement of allegations of violations found during triennial company examinations and for issuing policy forms to Texas consumers that varied from the versions of the forms filed with and approved by TDI.
Pharmacy benefits manager Optum Rx Inc. agreed to pay $5.8 million after allegedly failing to follow workers' compensation prescription pricing procedures.
